awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of TQ-ICP-MS for Geochemical Research in the Department of Earth and Environmental Science at the University of Minnesota
awd_abstract_narration:
This Division of Earth Sciences Instrumentation and Facilities Program award supports acquisition of an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) which will be used in support of Earth and Ocean science research and research training in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences at the University of Minnesota.   The instrument will support geochemical research that requires the ability to determine trace element concentrations and isotope ratios in natural fluids to better understand processes that occur in minerals-fluid interactions in high temperature hydrothermal systems in lakes and the oceans, the effects of biological activity on toxic elements introduced into the environment from mining and agricultural activity and for the study of the sedimentary record of Earth’s past climate dynamics. The instrument will support student training in methods of geochemical analysis and will serve as a departmental resource for environmental research on topics of societal relevance including studies with implications for human health hazards related to anthropogenic activities and remediation strategies.

Compositional variability of fluids coexisting with minerals in natural aquatic systems in time and space provides fundamental insight on a wide range of processes critical to the chemical evolution and climate history of Earth. Specific research and teaching activities that will benefit from this acquisition include: geochemical controls on sublacustrine and subaerial hydrothermal activity and associated biogeochemistry in Yellowstone National Park; microbially mediated mineral alteration, weathering, and metal and metalloid redox transformations; development of stable potassium isotopes as a novel proxy for the potassium cycle; and development, calibration and application of high resolution dating methods to study changes in Earth climate and ocean chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This project provided funds for the acquisition of an analytical instrument that can be used to measure trace concentrations of elements in complex aqueous (water-rich) fluids. The instrument has the unique capability of removing the influence of interfering chemicals in fluids on primary (target) elements, and thus, permits lower detection limits and quantification of elements critically important to resolving important research questions in the Earth Sciences.  Accordingly, the new instrument (TQ-ICP-MS) allows measurement of trace elements in rocks, minerals, natural groundwaters, seawater, seafloor hydrothermal vent fluids, and experimental run products. The chemical data acquired then permits important advances in our understanding of the following:

  • Contaminant transfer and how potentially toxic elements move through the near surface environment.
  • Geomicrobiology, elucidating how trace metals, such as selenium in water and soils, can be removed or enriched as a consequence of microbial metabolism.
  • Determination of trace elements in cave deposits that can serve as proxies for the timing and extent of climate change in the geological past, with implications for the future.  
  • Chemical composition of marine hot spring fluids that can affect the chemical evolution of the oceans on Earth.

In addition to these research objectives (intellectual merit), the TQ-ICP-MS is now used in analytical geochemistry courses at the University of Minnesota, providing analytical skills for the next generation of students and young professionals, enhancing career objectives. To further this objective, workshop have been arranged at the University of Minnesota for enhanced learning opportunities amongst user groups. Thus, a very positive leaning environment has been created for the common good. More broadly, data dissemination is now starting to occur through publication of scientific data in peer reviewed journals.  

The TQ-ICP-MS has filled a critical need in the analytical capabilities and resources in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences (physical infrastructure) at the University of Minnesota. The instrument, in particular, bridges capabilities of other instruments, and thus, enhances greatly the full range of instrumentation available to student and faculty in their pursuit of research and education goals.  

 


Last Modified: 05/05/2022
Modified by: William E Seyfried
